title: Reviewing 2024 Destruction in EVE Online – The Year of the Fake Kill Mail
description: I did it last year so I am going to do it again this year.  I have concatenated the twelve monthly killdump.csv files from the Monthly Economic reports for 2024 and pulled them into PowerBI to see if I can find anything at all interesting to say about a full year of data.  The odds […]
author: Wilhelm Arcturus
excerpt: I did it last year so I am going to do it again this year. I have concatenated the twelve monthly killdump.csv files from the Monthly Economic reports for 2024 and pulled them into PowerBI to see …
text: I did it last year so I am going to do it again this year.  I have concatenated the twelve monthly killdump.csv files from the Monthly Economic reports for 2024 and pulled them into PowerBI to see if I can find anything at all interesting to say about a full year of data.  The odds of being interesting are not in my favor, but when has that ever stopped me before. EVE Online nerds harder As noted previously, I also wanted to compare the totals to what CCP announced in their extremely brief glance at destruction in the year end edition of The Pulse, which featured one big number. Specifically, CCP’s end of year video announced that total ISK destruction had been 966,404,782,603,070. The number from The Pulse That is a big number, and I’ll just shorthand that to 966 trillion ISK for ease of use. That number is SO big as to be ridiculous when compared to what CCP has reported in the MER every month, which totals up to 521,008,792,942,469 ISK, or 521 trillion ISK to keep things manageable. This is the same problem I noted last year, where the community team is announcing numbers that are not anchored in reality relative to what CCP tells us elsewhere.  Last year I considered that possibly the community team doesn’t know how to interpret numbers from the MER, speculating that they were adding up the “loss” and “destruction” numbers, which would be incorrect. However, this year loss+destruction doesn’t get us anywhere close to the number announced in The Pulse, falling a good 88 trillion shy of the mark, so I have changed my theory. I have changed my theory and now just assume that the community team doesn’t look at the MER at all… and it wouldn’t take much to convince me that CCP doesn’t look at the MER at all either.  It certainly isn’t great that they put together these number for us then ignore them otherwise. The MER could very well be just some data they dump on us monthly without ever looking at it as what it reports certainly doesn’t seem to influence any decisions they make. Anyway, I suspect that the community team just adds up numbers from zKillboard and publishes those. That is not necessarily a bad thing. One of the things I have noted in the past is that CCP is not very good at estimating the value of ships and in their “all embedded in HTML so I cannot extract any useful data from it” monthly battles summary they report both the CCP estimated value of the destruction as well as the zKillboard value, which is inevitably much higher. What that means is what the community team says is completely detached from what CCP reports in the MER… and I also think they don’t even look at the MER, but that is just my bias at this point. And with that you might well ask if I should just stop right here and cease this fruitless monthly and annual reporting on destruction in New Eden if my numbers aren’t… real?  Is “real” the word I am looking for to describe pretend numbers in a pretend location in a video game? Anyway, I am invested already, so I won’t stop.  Not yet anyway.  As I repeated often during the SuperData chart era, even incorrect data has value if collected in a consistent way.  Absolute values may be incorrect, but valid trends will still be visible.  And the actual count of losses is likely to be more accurate, it is just ISK that CCP is bad at.  For all its merits, zKillboard can’t grab every loss mail.  So off we go, fingers in ears, loudly going, “Lalalalalala I can’t hear you!” as you raise your objections about the data I am about to present. Overall Summary – Was 2024 a Good Year for New Eden? At first glance 2024 certainly looks like it was a good year for losses, considering that there wasn’t any sort of major war in null sec.  But we’ll get to regions and locations for losses.  The total values for 2024 were: 2024 Total Losses: 5,886,112 2024 Total Value: 521.01 trillion ISK Avg Losses per month: 490,509 Avg Value Lost per month: 43.42 trillion ISK The previous benchmark year was 2020, when the pandemic got us all to stay home and have a really big war in null sec where everybody piled on Goons and we had Guinness Book world record setting battles and lost trillions of ISK over somewhat minor objectives.  What did 2020 look like and how did it square up to 2024? 2020 Total Losses 5,674,137 (2024 had 211,975 more losses) 2020 Total Value 459.45 trillion ISK (2024 had 61.56 trillion ISK more in losses) Avg Losses per month 472,845 Avg Value Lost per month 38.29 trillion ISK By the numbers, 2024 looks like it eclipsed the activity of 2020, without even a major null sec war.  How can that be?  Is low sec just that hot still with the Havoc expansion? Well, the difference in total losses is inflated by the now rampant AIR Career Program skill point farming.  As we’ll get to later, there were almost 400K losses in Uitra, including almost 300K shuttle losses, all due to farming skill points.  That wasn’t happening on such a grand scale until 2022 or so. Meanwhile, the ISK lost… that is mostly due to long term effects of CCP’s ill considered scarcity plan which made everything more expensive.  The game hasn’t recovered from that still and CCP continues to stand by its mineral bottlenecks in a “one step forward, two steps back” approach to maintaining scarcity. So you can see more than a 5 trillion gap in the average losses per month… and there is an underlying average price per loss of 82.29 million ISK in 2020 versus 88.54 million ISK per loss in 2024… is suppressed by the fact that a huge number of the losses are shuttles blow up for AIR Career Program goals. If you remove Uitra from the totals… you don’t even have to get to the other systems where people are doing this… 2020 remains the benchmark for activity.  2024 was the year of the AIR Career Program and the ongoing CCP ruination of the economy. Congratulations all around! And you should keep this in mind when you look at things like Jester’s charts, where logins are also no doubt being inflated somewhat by people sitting in Uitra working on skill point farming.  I mean sure, they are logged into and playing the game, but if people are drawn to what is arguably an exploit, is that a good thing?  You make the call! Anyway, just to round this out, the data for the intervening years starting with 2023: 2023 Total Losses: 5,212,934 (2024 had 673,178 more losses) 2023 Total Value: 478.99 trillion ISK (2024 had 159.51 trillion ISK more in losses) Avg Losses per month: 434,411 Avg Value Lost per month: 39.92 trillion ISK 2022: 2022 Total Losses: 4,497,590 (2024 had 1,388,522 more losses) 2022 Total Value: 361.49 trillion ISK (2024 had 159.51 trillion trillion ISK more in losses) Avg Losses per month: 374,799 Avg Value Lost per month: 30.12 trillion 2021: 2021 Total Losses: 4,899,115 (2024 had 986,997 more losses) 2021 Total Value: 408.49 trillion ISK (2024 had 112.52 trillion ISK more in losses) Avg Losses per month 408,260 Avg Value Lost per month 34.04 trillion In the end, we’re better off than the 2022 and the Year of Disappointment, but 2020 remains a high point for the game… and apparently a period that CCP has decided was a bad for New Eden and which it has actively preventing from occurring again. Top 20 Most Frequent Losses by Class and Hull The usual suspects that I pull in every month. Capsules dominate the count because everybody has one and a lot of them get destroyed. Meanwhile, 1 in 8 losses in New Eden are shuttles… even with capsules in the calculation of the whole.  If we remove capsules that brings the loss total down to 4,403,653 and the percentage of the remainder is about 17.5% of losses, which is a little more than 1 in 6 losses in New Eden. Again, this is the corruption of the data by the AIR Career Program… and I do not doubt I will feel the need to bring that up again a few more times as we progress through the data. Hulls Recorded as Lost only Once in 2024 For the monthly data I usually filter out the POS structures and fighter groups.  But given 12 months of data, why not see what only got blown up once in 2024 according to CCP? Kinakka Black Rise 1.68 trillion 0.32% TDP-T3 Perrigen Falls           22,751 0.39% I will declare that ISK losses is the real measurement for how destructive a system really is.  Ahbazon, a cross-roads low sec system astride the short route between Jita and Amarr is a hot spot for interdicting traffic.  By taking Ahbazon the route between the two trade hubs is 12 gates.  But if you want the safe route is 46 gates, causing people to decide to risk it. The short route from Amarr to Jita… the arbitrage trail of tears Not that trade interdiction is all that happens in Ahbazon, but it is part of its fame. Meanwhile, Uitra makes a mockery of the destruction count side of the table, where it sits in first place with three times to number as second place Jita.  But when it comes to ISK Jita is still in second place which Uitra is way down in 3,344th position.  Uitra remains the center of New Eden for staged, fake kills. 2024 and the Uitra Connection Since I am apparently not going to let go of the whole Uitra thing quite yet, let’s just drag some more numbers out into the light of day, including what blew up in Uitra in 2024. The highest total of losses are for the Gnosis hull, which has to be from people forgetting to correctly challenge a duel and getting CONCORDed.  As I described in my post about doing the AIR Career Program, it is the ideal ship for getting electronic and capacitor warfare options handled as well as shield and armor reps.  That has to be from people being sloppy.  I cannot imagine people throwing away a 40 million combat battlecruiser hull on purpose. The legend says that an old gypsy woman declared that New Eden will only survive so long as the POS code remains in the EVE Online code base.  CCP has, at times, declared their intent to remove the noble POS from the game, taking the POS code with it.  But it has never come to pass. Some say that is because CCP still sees the utility of the POS or that the developer time to remove the code is not worth the effort.  And some believe that Hilmar looked into the eyes of the gypsy woman as she made this declaration and blinked… only to open his eyes again to find she had disappeared.  Or maybe she was never there.  But the company seems to not want to chance fate, so you can still manufacture, deploy, and destroy POSes in the game. 2024 Monthly Destruction Posts Just the monthly posts if you want to go back into data for a more specific point in 2024. January February March April May June July August September October November December Notes Finally, just a technical note, how did I concatenate those files? I renamed them all to add in the month and pulled each into a single directory, so there were a dozen files there with a name like “killdump_04.csv.”  Then I opened up a command prompt in Windows and used the command: copy *.csv combined2024killdump.csv That went through and pulled all the .csv files into a single .csv as named in the command. Then I used my standard monthly review template in PowerBI and pointed it at that file, waited a while because it takes a bit to parse 900MB of .csv data. I did not have any errors this time because I remembered to go in and remove I had left the first row, with the titles, from all but the first file in Notepad++.  Piece of cake, all months together in one file. As it turned out I totally lost my Notepad++ notes about doing this, so the fact that I included this section in the 2023 post paid off.  Adding it again so I will be able to find it in 2026.
html:
I did it last year so I am going to do it again this year.  I have concatenated the twelve monthly killdump.csv files from the Monthly Economic reports for 2024 and pulled them into PowerBI to see if I can find anything at all interesting to say about a full year of data.  The odds of being interesting are not in my favor, but when has that ever stopped me before.

EVE Online nerds harder

As noted previously, I also wanted to compare the totals to what CCP announced in their extremely brief glance at destruction in the year end edition of The Pulse, which featured one big number.

Specifically, CCP’s end of year video announced that total ISK destruction had been 966,404,782,603,070.

The number from The Pulse

That is a big number, and I’ll just shorthand that to 966 trillion ISK for ease of use.

That number is SO big as to be ridiculous when compared to what CCP has reported in the MER every month, which totals up to 521,008,792,942,469 ISK, or 521 trillion ISK to keep things manageable.

This is the same problem I noted last year, where the community team is announcing numbers that are not anchored in reality relative to what CCP tells us elsewhere.  Last year I considered that possibly the community team doesn’t know how to interpret numbers from the MER, speculating that they were adding up the “loss” and “destruction” numbers, which would be incorrect.

However, this year loss+destruction doesn’t get us anywhere close to the number announced in The Pulse, falling a good 88 trillion shy of the mark, so I have changed my theory.

I have changed my theory and now just assume that the community team doesn’t look at the MER at all… and it wouldn’t take much to convince me that CCP doesn’t look at the MER at all either.  It certainly isn’t great that they put together these number for us then ignore them otherwise. The MER could very well be just some data they dump on us monthly without ever looking at it as what it reports certainly doesn’t seem to influence any decisions they make.

Anyway, I suspect that the community team just adds up numbers from zKillboard and publishes those.

That is not necessarily a bad thing.

One of the things I have noted in the past is that CCP is not very good at estimating the value of ships and in their “all embedded in HTML so I cannot extract any useful data from it” monthly battles summary they report both the CCP estimated value of the destruction as well as the zKillboard value, which is inevitably much higher.

What that means is what the community team says is completely detached from what CCP reports in the MER… and I also think they don’t even look at the MER, but that is just my bias at this point.

And with that you might well ask if I should just stop right here and cease this fruitless monthly and annual reporting on destruction in New Eden if my numbers aren’t… real?  Is “real” the word I am looking for to describe pretend numbers in a pretend location in a video game?

Anyway, I am invested already, so I won’t stop.  Not yet anyway.  As I repeated often during the SuperData chart era, even incorrect data has value if collected in a consistent way.  Absolute values may be incorrect, but valid trends will still be visible.  And the actual count of losses is likely to be more accurate, it is just ISK that CCP is bad at.  For all its merits, zKillboard can’t grab every loss mail.  So off we go, fingers in ears, loudly going, “Lalalalalala I can’t hear you!” as you raise your objections about the data I am about to present.

Overall Summary – Was 2024 a Good Year for New Eden?

At first glance 2024 certainly looks like it was a good year for losses, considering that there wasn’t any sort of major war in null sec.  But we’ll get to regions and locations for losses.  The total values for 2024 were:

  • 2024 Total Losses: 5,886,112
  • 2024 Total Value: 521.01 trillion ISK
  • Avg Losses per month: 490,509
  • Avg Value Lost per month: 43.42 trillion ISK

The previous benchmark year was 2020, when the pandemic got us all to stay home and have a really big war in null sec where everybody piled on Goons and we had Guinness Book world record setting battles and lost trillions of ISK over somewhat minor objectives.  What did 2020 look like and how did it square up to 2024?

  • 2020 Total Losses 5,674,137 (2024 had 211,975 more losses)
  • 2020 Total Value 459.45 trillion ISK (2024 had 61.56 trillion ISK more in losses)
  • Avg Losses per month 472,845
  • Avg Value Lost per month 38.29 trillion ISK

By the numbers, 2024 looks like it eclipsed the activity of 2020, without even a major null sec war.  How can that be?  Is low sec just that hot still with the Havoc expansion?

Well, the difference in total losses is inflated by the now rampant AIR Career Program skill point farming.  As we’ll get to later, there were almost 400K losses in Uitra, including almost 300K shuttle losses, all due to farming skill points.  That wasn’t happening on such a grand scale until 2022 or so.

Meanwhile, the ISK lost… that is mostly due to long term effects of CCP’s ill considered scarcity plan which made everything more expensive.  The game hasn’t recovered from that still and CCP continues to stand by its mineral bottlenecks in a “one step forward, two steps back” approach to maintaining scarcity.

So you can see more than a 5 trillion gap in the average losses per month… and there is an underlying average price per loss of 82.29 million ISK in 2020 versus 88.54 million ISK per loss in 2024… is suppressed by the fact that a huge number of the losses are shuttles blow up for AIR Career Program goals.

If you remove Uitra from the totals… you don’t even have to get to the other systems where people are doing this… 2020 remains the benchmark for activity.  2024 was the year of the AIR Career Program and the ongoing CCP ruination of the economy.

Congratulations all around!

And you should keep this in mind when you look at things like Jester’s charts, where logins are also no doubt being inflated somewhat by people sitting in Uitra working on skill point farming.  I mean sure, they are logged into and playing the game, but if people are drawn to what is arguably an exploit, is that a good thing?  You make the call!

Anyway, just to round this out, the data for the intervening years starting with 2023:

  • 2023 Total Losses: 5,212,934 (2024 had 673,178 more losses)
  • 2023 Total Value: 478.99 trillion ISK (2024 had 159.51 trillion ISK more in losses)
  • Avg Losses per month: 434,411
  • Avg Value Lost per month: 39.92 trillion ISK

2022:

  • 2022 Total Losses: 4,497,590 (2024 had 1,388,522 more losses)
  • 2022 Total Value: 361.49 trillion ISK (2024 had 159.51 trillion trillion ISK more in losses)
  • Avg Losses per month: 374,799
  • Avg Value Lost per month: 30.12 trillion

2021:

  • 2021 Total Losses: 4,899,115 (2024 had 986,997 more losses)
  • 2021 Total Value: 408.49 trillion ISK (2024 had 112.52 trillion ISK more in losses)
  • Avg Losses per month 408,260
  • Avg Value Lost per month 34.04 trillion

In the end, we’re better off than the 2022 and the Year of Disappointment, but 2020 remains a high point for the game… and apparently a period that CCP has decided was a bad for New Eden and which it has actively preventing from occurring again.

Meanwhile, 1 in 8 losses in New Eden are shuttles… even with capsules in the calculation of the whole.  If we remove capsules that brings the loss total down to 4,403,653 and the percentage of the remainder is about 17.5% of losses, which is a little more than 1 in 6 losses in New Eden.

Again, this is the corruption of the data by the AIR Career Program… and I do not doubt I will feel the need to bring that up again a few more times as we progress through the data.

I will declare that ISK losses is the real measurement for how destructive a system really is.  Ahbazon, a cross-roads low sec system astride the short route between Jita and Amarr is a hot spot for interdicting traffic.  By taking Ahbazon the route between the two trade hubs is 12 gates.  But if you want the safe route is 46 gates, causing people to decide to risk it.

The short route from Amarr to Jita… the arbitrage trail of tears

Not that trade interdiction is all that happens in Ahbazon, but it is part of its fame.

Meanwhile, Uitra makes a mockery of the destruction count side of the table, where it sits in first place with three times to number as second place Jita.  But when it comes to ISK Jita is still in second place which Uitra is way down in 3,344th position.  Uitra remains the center of New Eden for staged, fake kills.

The legend says that an old gypsy woman declared that New Eden will only survive so long as the POS code remains in the EVE Online code base.  CCP has, at times, declared their intent to remove the noble POS from the game, taking the POS code with it.  But it has never come to pass.

Some say that is because CCP still sees the utility of the POS or that the developer time to remove the code is not worth the effort.  And some believe that Hilmar looked into the eyes of the gypsy woman as she made this declaration and blinked… only to open his eyes again to find she had disappeared.  Or maybe she was never there.  But the company seems to not want to chance fate, so you can still manufacture, deploy, and destroy POSes in the game.

Notes

Finally, just a technical note, how did I concatenate those files?

I renamed them all to add in the month and pulled each into a single directory, so there were a dozen files there with a name like “killdump_04.csv.”  Then I opened up a command prompt in Windows and used the command:

copy *.csv combined2024killdump.csv

That went through and pulled all the .csv files into a single .csv as named in the command.

Then I used my standard monthly review template in PowerBI and pointed it at that file, waited a while because it takes a bit to parse 900MB of .csv data.

I did not have any errors this time because I remembered to go in and remove I had left the first row, with the titles, from all but the first file in Notepad++.  Piece of cake, all months together in one file.

As it turned out I totally lost my Notepad++ notes about doing this, so the fact that I included this section in the 2023 post paid off.  Adding it again so I will be able to find it in 2026.
